review.title: Simple Algorithm Portfolio for SAT
review.abstract: The importance of algorithm portfolio techniques for SAT has long been noted, and a number of very successful systems have been devised, including the most successful one --- SATzilla. However, all these systems are quite complex (to understand, reimplement, or modify). In this paper we propose a new algorithm portfolio for SAT that is extremely simple, but in the same time so efficient that it outperforms SATzilla. For a new SAT instance to be solved, our portfolio finds its k-nearest neighbors from the training set and invokes a solver that performs the best at those instances. The main distinguishing feature of our algorithm portfolio is the locality of the selection procedure --- the selection of a SAT solver is based only on few instances similar to the input one.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 110 7.02 68v2 [cs.AI] 13 DKeywords algorithm portfolios, SAT solution

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This observation leads to algorithm portfolios, which select one from several available solvers who are expected to perform best in a given instance. This selection is based on data on the performance of available solvers on a large number of instances. The problem of the algorithm portfolio is not limited to M. Nikolic "Faculty of Mathematics, Belgrade, Serbia E-mail: filip @ matf.bg.ac.rsP. Janic" ic "s Faculty of Mathematics, Belgrade, Serbia E-Mail: filip @ matf.bg.ac.rsP. Janic" ic "s Faculty of Mathematics, University of Blegrade, Belgrade, Serbia E-Mail: filip."

sections.heading: 2 Algorithm Portfolios for SAT
sections.text: The different approaches to the algorithm portfolio for SAT and related problems have been predicted (Gomes & Selman, 2001; Horvitz et al., 2001; Lagoudakis & Littman, 2001; Samulowitz & Memisevic, 2007), but the turning point in the field has been marked by the emergence of the SATzilla portfolio (Nudelman, Brown, Hoos, Devkar, & Shoham, 2004; Xu et al, 2008).Here we describe several current relevant approaches to selecting algorithms, most of them using fragments of the SATzilla methodology. SATzilla, the algorithm portfolio that has dominated recent SAT competitions, is the most important and successful algorithm portfolio for SAT, with admirable performance (Xu et al., 2008; Xu, Hutter, Hoos & LeytonBrown, 2009).

sections.heading: 3 Nearest Neighbor-Based Algorithm Portfolio
sections.text: Existing SAT portfolio systems build their models (e.g. runtime prediction models, grouping of instances, etc.) in advance, regardless of the characteristics of the input instance. We expect that a finer selection of algorithms could be achieved when building and using a local, input-specific model. However, a simple model of this kind can be achieved by the next adjacent method (Duda, Hart, & Stork, 2001), of only a few instances that are similar to the instance that is solved. In the rest of this section, we describe our algorithm portfolio for SAT. It is assumed that a training set of instances is solved by all solvers from the portfolio, and that the solution times are available (within a given cutoff time). Based on these solution times, a penalty can be calculated for each instance (the longer resolution time, the greater penalty). Each instance is represented by a vector of features.

sections.heading: 4 Implementation and Experimental Evaluation
sections.text: This year, it has reached the point where it will be able to put itself at the top of the list in the way that it is able to put itself at the top.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: The system presented, ArgoSmArT kNN, benefits from the SATzilla system in several ways: it uses a subset of SATzilla functions to represent instances, a selection of SAT solvers, SATzilla solution data for the training corpus, and fragments of the SATzilla implementation. However, the proposed system differs significantly from SATzilla. Instead of predicting runtimes, our system chooses a solver based on knowledge of instances from the local neighborhood of the input instance, using the k-next-neighbor method. The proposed system is implemented and publicly available as open source. Experimental evaluation shows that the particular decisions made in the design of our system are even better than the decisions made in the similar current system (malital-SAT method), which is the most successful (SATT algorithm version), not necessarily, but is the most successful.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This work was partially supported by the grant of the Serbian Ministry of Science 174021 and the SNSF grant SCOPES IZ73Z0 127979 / 1. We thank Xu Lin for clarifying some questions related to the training data and the Mathematical Institute of the Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts for permission to use their computer resources.

, 2001; Lagoudakis & Littman, 2001; Samulowitz & Memisevic, 2007), but the turning point in the field has been marked by the appearance of SATzilla portfolio (Nudelman, Brown, Hoos, Devkar, & Shoham, 2004; Xu et al., 2008).

SATzilla, the algorithm portfolio that has been dominating recent SAT Competitions, is the most important and the most successful algorithm portfolio for SAT, with admirable performance (Xu et al., 2008; Xu, Hutter, Hoos, & LeytonBrown, 2009).
ArgoSmArT is a system developed for instance-based selection of policies for a single SAT solver (Nikolić et al., 2009).
As a suitable underlying SAT solver it uses a modular solver ArgoSAT (Marić, 2009).

However, there are special optimization based techniques for finding good solver configurations off-line (Hutter et al., 2009; Ansótegui et al., 2009).

SATzilla was trained using 5883 instances from SAT Competitions (2002-2005 and 2007) and SAT Races 2006 and 2008 (Xu et al., 2009).
There are 13 solvers for which the solving data are available, and that are used by SATzilla 2009 as components solvers in 3 versions of SATzilla (random, crafted, and industrial) (Xu et al., 2009).

In our experimental comparison, we included MXC08 (the best single solver on the training set), SATzilla, the ArgoSmArT system based on (Nikolić et al., 2009) with 13 SATzillasolvers instead of ArgoSAT configurations, ArgoSmArT 1-NN, and ArgoSmArT 9-NN.

We presented a strikingly simple algorithm portfolio for SAT stemming from our work on ArgoSmArT (Nikolić et al., 2009).
The experimental evaluation shows that the particular decisions made in the design of our system are even better than the decisions made in the similar recent system (Malitsky et al., 2011).

metadata.abstractText: The importance of algorithm portfolio techniques for SAT has long been noted, and a number of very successful systems have been devised, including the most successful one — SATzilla. However, all these systems are quite complex (to understand, reimplement, or modify). In this paper we present an algorithm portfolio for SAT that is extremely simple, but in the same time so efficient that it outperforms SATzilla. For a new SAT instance to be solved, our portfolio finds its k-nearest neighbors from the training set and invokes a solver that performs the best for those instances. The main distinguishing feature of our algorithm portfolio is the locality of the selection procedure — the selection of a SAT solver is based only on few instances similar to the input one. An open source tool that implements our approach is publicly available.
